commentBody: In reply to the column: RE might look like it's an abbreviation for "regarding", but it's not. It's a form of the Latin word res, meaning thing, related to the English word "real", and believe it or not, "rebus". https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/re https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/rebus The fact that it stands in for "regarding" is a coincidence, much like the English "much" and the Spanish "mucho" have completely different etymologies.

And now about the puzzle itself:

I solved this one in less than half my average Sunday time, and considerably faster than the Saturday puzzle.  On the other hand, the theme sort of left me cold.  I get it; I understand it; it just didn't do very much for me.  Maybe that's just me, but that's how I found it.

My limited knowledge of Indian words (Hindi, I guess) includes ALOO meaning potato, but does that mean that GOBI means cauliflower?  Then it would be the Cauliflower Desert, wouldn't it?  Lemme look...

Apparently, the Hindi word for cauliflower is फूलगोभी
(phoolagobhee), so maybe a shortened form?

And that was about the only non-theme answer of any interest to me in this very workaday puzzle.

As for the theme, there are literally hundreds of words in English that begin in RE; if those letters show up yellow in Wordle, they go directly at the beginning...unless they go at the end, where they're also extremely common.  The best theme sets are those for which there are hardly any other--or no other--possible examples.  This was the opposite of that.  So what you know after one or two correct answers is that you're going to find an RE in the middle of all of them.

Hardly cause for excitement.

Somehow, I expect a more interesting puzzle from Jeff Chen.
Maybe it's just me, but I think "Dogcatcher?" would be a better clue for 86-A.
Was so on the same page as the creator.  New personal best.  Quite fun.  Good work!!

I'm starting to get annoyed with myself. I hurry to complete a puzzle without fully grasping the theme sometimes. I'm too focused on speed, it seems, and not enough on taking a moment to just let things percolate. 
Today exemplifies that perfectly, and I think it's a gem of a puzzle!
Light work for a Sunday.  Otoh, not a single niche cultural signifier.
Some may say too easy.  I say with all that's going on in the rest of the NYT, I welcome the smooth sailing of this friction-free solve from Rich and Jeff!

Whoa! I can't believe how fast I finished this one—less than half my average. If I hadn't taken a call from my husband and forgot to stop the timer, it would have been a personal best, but no regrets. After all, IMINLOVE! 

I've gotten better over the last 16 months or so, but I'm definitely not that good or fast, and I don't particularly try to be fast. Even the couple things I didn't know, like RONDOS, filled in with no trouble. The only resistance was trying to remember how to spell ECHINACEA, which I knew right away but just left at ECHIN until I was sure. 

It was an enjoyable enough romp, not a SLOG, but I missed trying to figure things out more, like I expect with Sunday puzzles, which I have all the time in the world to puzzle out. Today the theme just filled itself in. 

24D made me smile because it made me think of the ever incredulous Hastings on the David Suchet version of TV's Poirot. I'm not big on Agatha Christie adaptions but I enjoy that one. It always cracks us up when he says it. 

LETSEAT ALOOGOBI!!!  Yes, let's!!! It's my favorite! Sorry, I get a bit overly enthused by Indian food. 

Saturday, we had GINMARTINIS, my favorite (even if I think MARTINI shouldn't have to be modified by saying GIN... unless you want a particular gin) but today's STOLI is for you vodka martini drinkers. Cheers to you! 

Think I might just shake me up one a little early tonight...  Hendrick's GIN for me, thank you very much!

Stoner who kept on praising this puzzle?
HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

Disgust with body builders?
GAG REFLEX

History course on the Civil War?
CLASS REUNION

Well, it's been an easy weekend, but a fun one. I'd go outside to look at the moon but it's raining here (NEGATIVE REVIEW).

Fun, easy solve, but I didn't catch the theme and wondered what the title referred to and what was the deal with the "re" repetition. I print it out, so I didn't see Will's intro, but the second I saw the reference to "double entendre," I finally got it. Glad I didn't see that beforehand--I think it would've spoiled it! Great job, Rich and Jeff!

Lines from Genesis? ... or NYT crossword to some



DAILYRECREATION
Can someone please help me understand how [Chestnuts] clues to OLDSAWS. Thanks. Google was no help.

Quite a breezy Sunday. It took me a few theme answers before I fully grasped the theme,  but a lot of the fill was quite predictable. Glad to see ALOO GOBI. I am quite partial to Indian food and this is one of the few dishes I can actually make myself. 

A bull or a heifer?  GENDER REVEAL
I enjoyed it! Unusual in a stimulating way!
Disappointing. More like a large Monday puzzle. Been solving NY Times puzzles since '72. Missed the usual cleverness that I look forward to in the Sunday puzzle.
Sunday record!

Blissful when the tiramisu is served?

SPIRITUAL RETREAT

And that will have to do, because Steve L is right - there are so many. 
I could do more, if they didn’t have to be good, haha!
Rich and Jeff chose some fun ones, and it took me awhile to figure out what was going on. Puzzlement achieved.

Crossword Revolution (CR) Day 19: ALOO GOBI

I must admit to feeling rejuvenated about the CR after getting some generous and encouraging feedback yesterday, including an  enlightened explanation of just what the heck I’m doing by @Kate Tani: “one part algospeak,* one part deference to crosswords’ function as a non-political escape (meaning obscured exactly for this reason), and one part acknowledgement that everything tastes like what’s happening politically right now.”

ALOO GOBI might be taking that last part a little too literally, but revolutionaries must eat and I do love vegetarian Indian food, including ALOO GOBI.  

*  “Algospeak refers to coded language and euphemisms used on social media platforms to avoid having content removed or filtered by an algorithm.”  (Dictionary.com) 

A Crosswords Saved the Day ™ production.
Satisfying.

I wish the app would give you SOMETHING when you set a personal best. I don't need an animation or anything but having to back out to your stats page and select the day to see if you got it is a little anticlimactic. How about just a "Congratulations you just set a new record!" on the solved time page?

"Head of a noted animal rescue project" was worth the price of admission.

"Let's take it nice and easy" kind of puzzle - just what I needed.

Hope the week turns out to e a good one.
Happy puzzling!

Still on the easy side but probably the best of the preceding week.  Nice puzzle.  Thanks.

Theme was a little distracting but it actually helped in solving, so a good thing.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

112D - I wrote in LSAT when I read it, but only because it seemed like an obvious answer for a 4 letter clue about a lawyers. The question I have is, does one "pass" the LSAT? Unless the constructor is saying that you "pass by it" on your way. Seems odd.

Fun and smooth solve; sadly, one less thing to do on Sunday morning.  But I'll need the time to shovel the snow, and make the snacks for the Super Bowl party.  Looking for more distractions from the current state of affairs.
Really loved the theme

Well, that was ... brisk. After Saturday's non-starter, an easy fill with a straightforward theme.
Good to see TAM properly attributed, rather than pretending it's Scottish. Don't like BARB clued as [Spike], which it isn't. SWEEPS week was new to me, OTOE, LSAT, and NCAA old friends from previous encounters here. Don't think I know  the TBS (as opposed to PBS and CBS) channel.
But otherwise familiar stuff.
An enjoyable Sunday puzzle. The best one in weeks.
Interesting that the clue for Pluto could be GOD or DOG…Despite my interest in mythology I had the latter first
Straightforward, speedy and enjoyable. Nice work.
My fastest Sunday in 8 years of daily solving.
I approached this one with "great resolve." A very fun puzzle with an imaginative twist. It took a bit to see the wordplay, but then I caught on.
Well, that was fast.
9 minutes below average but only solved it due to the OLDSAWS hint in the comments. Only hint I needed though, understood the theme pretty quickly and thought it was very clever as a wordplay theme.
Fri/Sat/Sun felt like a Mon/Tue/Wed this week.

i've been an on-and-off nytimes puzzler since my college days in the 80s, and for many years i stayed away from friday and saturday puzzles. they were just too intimidating.

during covid, my then-teenaged son, aaron, and i started doing the puzzle together. i think the saying "two heads are better than one" especially applies to puzzling! and our various interests and knowledge combined very effectively. still, our longest streak was 100 and something days.

aaron went away for college for a few years, and our joint puzzling days were limited to school breaks and summer vacations. but then life happened and he decided that he wanted to come back home. and so, we got back to our puzzling.

we've had a number of pretty significant streaks over the years, but today (well, really tomorrow, but we completed sunday's puzzle tonight) we unlocked a new achievement: 366 days/one full year! friday and saturday puzzles no longer intimidate us, and our average times for those days have even gone down quite a bit.

reading wordplay after we solve a puzzle and scrolling through the comments here have definitely added to our fun. we've even worked on constructing some puzzles of our own, so who knows? maybe one day we'll get up the courage to submit a few.

so anyway, thanks for being such an informative, generally supportive, and occasionally hilarious puzzling community!

Ask for the fast train:  SPECIAL REQUEST

Habitual cough: CHAIN REACTION

Mistaken dog catcher:  SPOT REMOVER

Head on the desert:  A LOO GOBI

Rented bench:  LET SEAT
____________
Very cool puzzle:  THIS ONE

Thank you, Rich Katz and Jeff Chen, for this gently complicated puzzle—absorbing but not punishing, and with much to entertain.  We already have enough in the paper that can give us a headache.

57 seconds short of my Sunday record, which is probably one of two best times that are actually accurate, but I'm not disappointed. This was a fast, but amusing puzzle, and part of the speed was that the theme was so accessible and helped with the solve. There were only a few areas where I had to rely on crosses to fill in answers, and that helped as well.

Thanks Rich and Jeff!
Got stuck on SPECIALINQUEST for ages before the penny finally dropped. Fun puzzle, nice and breezy with some clever clueing.

You know who else whistles while they work?
Dwarves, that's who. 
Other than that, no problems with clues or theme.
Skipping the mini bc football, about which  I neither know c nor care.  Please have an opera puzzle to ,ake up for this.
Thanks Rich and Jeff. A blast!
A blistering 18:02, just a minute and change off my best Sunday ever. Loved it, the Dracula clue may be an all time favorite!

Quick and easy Sunday. I liked 5D DNA and the wordplay.  I’ve not seen MELONs in a fruit bowl.
Fun fact: the Bible makes no reference to the forbidden fruit being an apple. The clue in question, however, was clever enough that I will refrain from penning a strongly worded letter to the editor.

The fill was enjoyable, and the theme is clever — I’m learning about it now. I was having fun in the moment using downs to solve it, so I didn’t try to figure out the theme as I was going. It was pleasant experience nevertheless.

Like a dog wanting a reward before doing a trick?  




HASTY RETREAT



Et tu, emu.

I'm curious why 21 Down is clued as Vodka brand, informally. The cluing is out of date. The informal name STOLI was made the official name in 2022: https://www.npr.org/2022/03/07/1085053999/stolichnaya-vodka-stoli-ukraine-russia

Thoroughly enjoyable. 
Blanked on Oahu (DOH!) and Rondo
It’s a new PR for Sunday! Thanks for the ride, Jeff and Rich.

How to stop this? 
Noreelection.

I didn't even clock the RE: part of the puzzle so reading this article gave me an even greater appreciation for this puzzle ! I really enjoyed this, it was a nice Sunday for me. The hiphop/r&b references and the French language clues were right up my alley. Usually I'm filled with dread when a puzzle has lots of clues which require knowing the names of any of the actors/public figures, but it didn't hinder me in this one. Appreciate the Kendrick Lamar clue since he's performing at the Super Bowl today! Watching his show will be the second highlight of my day- after completing my NYT puzzles of course.

Fun puzzle. Typical slow start for me, of course, and had to cheat a bit early on, but a great 'aha' moment when I caught on the trick and then just had a great time working out each of the theme answers.

Was really surprised to see that most of the theme answers were debuts, as they are all quite familiar phrases. SPEECHRECOGNITION, CHAINREACTION, HIGHRESOLUTION? 

Again - just really surprised at that. 

Puzzle finds today were inspired by realizing that: 

SUPERBOWLSUNDAY

is 15 letters. Found a couple of quite amazing ones. I'll put those in replies. 

...

I love word quirks, and crosswords are proof that they abound in our language. I love how constructors find them through flashes of insight, or serendipity, then run with them in a puzzle’s theme.

Today, for instance, giving new meaning to words that start with RE and riffing on it.  I was greatly entertained as I uncovered the theme answers.  This was a hoot.

Something special about those theme answers – six of the seven have never appeared in the 80+ years of the Times puzzle, despite being very in-the-language and having punch. Terrific finds.  Bravo on that, Rich and Jeff!  (Only SPOT REMOVER is not a debut answer).

And while more than 18,000 answers that begin with RE have appeared in the NYT puzzle, I found it very hard to come up with quality alternate theme answers, and man, I tried.  Either I thought of a RE word and couldn’t come up with anything, or what I came up with fell flat.

So, I was not only entertained, but impressed.

Thank you, Rich and Jeff, for putting this together, and providing for a lovely gambol in the box today!

I got 1/10th of the way through this puzzle and thought that at some point it would get more difficult. Nope. For me, just a really dull puzzle. Last Monday's gave me more trouble. This one did absolutely nothing for me except to allow me to go to bed earlier. 

I did appreciate a couple of clues, such as [Bud after Jack, perhaps?] and the [noted animal rescuer]. And since I've been solving before many of the commenters were born, the Spanish muralist SERT is old crosswordese for me.  

I love a Sunday puzzle that's challenging, but eventually makes me smile at its cleverness. This one was just boring, and not what I would have expected from Jeff Chen. I suspect that many newer solvers loved this because they were able to complete it in record time, since it was so easy.
The Times delivered the weekend cakewalk we all probably needed right about now.

a reduction of reactive replies.

Revved to relax and rest,
regain the requisite renewal that
recoup my resolve regarding 
reaching readiness for re-entrance to the
realm of real work.

Regards,
(re)CC.

DO RE ME.

A clever puzzle but too fast and easy for a Sunday
What my late friend would have called "a real filler-inner."

Sunday best for me, at just shy of 24 minutes with no errors. Got the theme at SPECIALREQUEST, which certainly helped with the other thematic entries.

The clues for the themers seemed especially well done. Only "Broadway offering titled with dots and dashes?" for SHOWREMORSE seemed a bit dodgy.

Very solid puzzle, and not too many proper nouns, which I found especially helpful.

Enjoying my HIGH RE SOLUTION right now, before turning to ice removal and other chores.
Easier than a Monday puzzle but three or four  times more time consuming.  Other than keeping a streak going it was a waste of time.

I found this puzzle great fun and was delighted to solve a Sunday puzzle without needing cheats!  (Of course, this likely means too many will complain that it is too easy.)  Thank you for giving the average solver a fun break!  More, please?
Beat my Sunday record by > 2 minutes, completing a record week totaling -83:20 compared to my average times.

Some of you solvers would complain if you were hung with a new rope: Just sayin.

Light and breezy Sunday puzzle, just the way we like them.

Only challenge was LESTER instead of some misspelled variant of Leslie.

Thank you Rich and Jeff

This marks three in a row: puzzles that were easier than the norm (for their day).

All three were fun puzzles (I especially liked SPEECH RE: COGNITION today), so it's hard to complain, but a SOLUTION this speedy does not leave a lasting HIGH.

Still I hope the puzzle-makers and editors have some crunchy challenges coming our way in the next week.

Usually when I see Jeff Chen’s name my heart sinks a little; in a good way that is. I expect a tough, chewy grid. Today’s was not that, but it was still a delight so this is a thumbs up, not a complaint.
I kept waiting to hit the wall with a fiendish theme, as I couldn’t guess what it might be from the title. Instead it was a smile of (re)cognition as I understood where it was leading. HIGH RESOLUTION indeed.
Temporarily halted at the crossing of 33D with 46A. Living Dead? Wake? As no clue to the tributary. Threw random letters in until WAGE hit. Duh.
Head before HELM another momentary check, but otherwise my smoothest Sunday solve in EONs. 
Off to put 76A on now for a satisfying cuppa.

Absolutely _love_ this theme!    "Speach RE: Cognition".   Hilarious.    So funny, so fun. 
    I also liked "head of a noted animal rescue project"  NOAH.   (I had considered the national oceanic and atmospheric administration, before considering the correct century.   Despite the fact that they don't particularly focus on animals, to my knowledge...)
    I admit the question mark had me looking for a RE in 54 across "roadies" --  But it didn't throw me too badly.   Another good double entendre there.
     I'm so glad I found this one!    Thanks constructors and editors!
Speedy resolve. Esp nice if you proceed from NW to SE. Merci, Rich and Jeff!

Well....IN RE this puzzle:  Much Ado About Nothing Much.  
Sorry, guys.
I enjoyed the cute clues and misdirects in the rest of the puzzle more than I enjoyed the themers

It must be my age:  I put in "Living WILL" before I had to revise (even though I recently referenced "Living WAGE" in a Comment.

The PLUTO clues/entries were fun to unravel.

I liked being reminded of RONDOS....my clarinet instructor and I once played a Mozart duet; the sonata took a half-hour (the entire lesson time) and yes, ended with a lively RONDO.  It was  a peak experience after weeks of practice on my own....
So, those were the things that made the puzzle enjoyable for me.
Missed opportunity with DEcounting a vampire. Alas.
Is it just me?  I was bored to tears by this puzzle and I ripped right through it.  I didn’t think the theme was so original and it was all too easy.  What will I do with the rest of my day?

This is just to note, re Caitlyn’s column, that “re” is not an abbreviation. It is a full-fledged English preposition, derived from the Latin. And (my pet peeve) it does not need to be followed by a colon in the middle of a sentence, as almost everybody seems to think.

[Equivocate on questions about the "Queen of Rock 'n' Roll"?]






PUNT RETURNER
I got a high when I finally resolved the trick 🙂

I solve for pleasure, not to guess the theme (which usually goes over my head anyway until I read the comments). And I certainly don't do these things to see how fast I can get to the end. A crossword puzzle is a pleasant diversion, and I like to savor it and marvel at the skill that went into creating it. Great job guys 👍
I also thought of Steven Wright for Spot Remover.   Funny comedian. He also comes to mind when I’m flipping a light switch that apparently does nothing

Clue for 18A, cute!  

A straightforward puzzle to provide some distraction in these anxious days.

Within a minute of my best Sunday time ever, so I understand those who commented that they were disappointed it was an easy Sunday.

I don't solve for speed though, and although the solve was relatively painless, it was still enjoyable for me to figure out the theme and appreciate some of the trickier clues.  

I don't mind a kinder and gentler Sunday crossword every now and then. Sometimes it's what we need.  

CR!

As others have said, felt easy, especially so because I was familiar with most of the references. 

Search isn't working for me right now, and perhaps someone has already said, but with 51A I immediately thought of Robert MORSE. "How to Succeed" was the first Broadway production I ever saw, when the touring company came through Atlanta and we got to usher.

"Gain information of interest to a mob boss?"
WITNESSRELOCATION

That's all I got. The theme was pretty good, and well-executed, but the puzzle overall was not very challenging. Very little pure wordplay to sweeten the pot.
Pluto could be a god or a dog, which reminds me of the joke—what do you call a dyslexic atheist? Someone who doesn’t believe in dog.

Nice! A normal Sunday crossword unlike last Sunday's. Thank you.

Nuff Said.
what a fun and delightful puzzle! enjoyed this one to start off my Super Bowl Sunday :) go eagles!
I often skip Sundays as they can be such a slog (for me) but this puzzle was just the mental romp I needed, this morning. Thanks for the laughs!
A breezy few days ending in a Sunday personal best. Difficulty level peaked on Wednesday this week.

The theme was fun, but other than getting hung up on the SERT/DENT crossing and filling in ISINLOVE and being okay with SOO intersecting it, the puzzle felt too formulaic. It was a personal best Sunday time, and a chunk of that was spent on those entries I had a letter off. All said, though, the theme jokes are good souvenirs of the solve!
Easy on but fun “resolve.”  Now just have to wait for the big game and see which dog ends up with the ring.

This will be amusing to most of you-but here goes….

Today is my first time completing  a NYT Sunday puzzle. I started solving the Monday puzzles and progressed to Tuesday, and Wednesday.  Reading the comments, I’ve come to the conclusion these puzzles are easy for most. They sure aren’t for me but I enjoy the challenge. And I’m happy to complete the Sunday puzzle! 

Hurray!

I have a quibble with 112D - “It’s passed on the way to the bar, for short.”  While I assumed the answer to be LSAT, no one actually “passes” the LSAT. They simply get a score, which law schools then use for admission purposes.
Aah! Easy Sunday! I must admit, I never fully grasped the theme, just filled out with help from the downs. Came here for my “THATS what it was all about” moment.

This was a fun Sunday. The blog’s guidance and help from the community have given me a very precious pastime. 

I also want to raise a glass to the Times Puzzles programmers and the creators who guided them. IMHO they’ve done a really fine job with all the puzzles and they keep making small but significant improvements. Eg, recently allowing repeating keys from my hardware keyboard. Also I’m impressed with the fact that I can share my results without revealing any answers. That’s forethought. Small but important details. I’ll shut up now. LOL! 

Bravo!

PSA about ECHINACEA:
As someone who's been interested in herbs and alternative medicines for some thirty years, I share with you that echinacea is considered as  nature's antibiotic.
As such, it should be taken as needed, and never continuously as prevention.
End of PSA. 😉 Onto the puzzle.

The themed RE went over my head. I don't like it when that happens. It makes me feel not that I myself failed, but moreso that I failed the constructor(s) by not honoring their ingenuity.

Other than that, I enjoyed this puzzle very much.
I did half of it last night and hit a wall, only to have it flow this morning after good sleep and coffee. 

Memorable entry: [Ones moving with the music] for ROADIES.

Thank you much, Messieurs!
Highly enjoyable Sunday puzzle!  And I'm still chuckling about Bud after Jack.  Great clue.

Solved it without lookups while also not getting the theme at all. After reading the wordplay it makes sense and then AFTER reading wordplay column the theme title “What’s it all about” makes sense. Though to put that theme together without reading minds but at least the rest of the puzzle was manageable

I was completely foxed by yesterday's Strands. It was "Westminster assembly". Obviously the UK parliament. But no, the answers were about dogs. After some searching I discover that it was about a  "famed dog show"! I don't have a dog (two cats) and had no idea. 
So much to learn ..

This was a fun puzzle that was fairly challenging but not in a scary I-can't-do-this, way.

I appreciated the theme and how, once it became clear, it helped with the solving process.

Nice write up Caitlin, except that re “re” you’ve been misled. It’s not short for “regarding” but rather derives from Latin meaning “by the thing” and in English it’s generally considered to mean “in the matter of”. Grammatically it substitutes well for “regarding”, but that’s not the same as actual etymology. Also, it’s pronounced with a short e, sounding like ray, rather than the beginning of regard.
Could get it b/c i was just sure it was a SIGH RE: SOLUTION

As some others have said, it felt a bit easy for a Sunday to me, but I really liked this puzzle none the less! My time is pretty inaccurate as I left the page open while making my kids' breakfast (oops!) otherwise I think this could have been close to a record for me as it wasn't far off from my average.
Very nice puzzle with a clever theme leading to a quick smooth solve once I noticed the third "re," but never in my life have I encountered the phrase "hive mind" in print or conversation.

May I humbly tho’ gleefully let thee know 
That after toilsome years that total four
On me today a divine glow
My first streak of seven, love it to the core.

For "Hardly a romp", I had SNOG. Mind is in the gutter and I didn't know the name of the tributary. 

Otherwise, a very enjoyable puzzle. I just need to think with my brain.

Such a clever theme! I enjoyed it so much, I went through and filled in most of them before I did the rest of the puzzle. Then I worked around the theme answers and filled the puzzle in that way. HIGHRESOLUTION was maybe my favorite...or maybe not.. I don't know; I just thought they were all so clever! A perfect Sunday for me!

I also had five cups of coffee today, and maybe that helped?

I love the 1980s Steven Wright reference! (Hi Caitlin, from your HCHS calc seatmate Dohra - we may have listened to Steven Wright audio albums at Julie Simos’s house.)
sorry to be a pedant but churros are not a Mexican pastry :/

May I mention a personal win from this week? No, I didn't finish the Sunday in a new world's record time, but I DID finish every puzzle this week, and with no peeking! Astonishing! Perhaps the coming late week puzzles will bring back the expected frustration, but today, I'll bask in the glow of my rare achievement, if you will indulge me. Keep going all, hope is powerful.

I liked the theme, and finished under my average time, in spite of stopping regularly to watch the commercials during the superbowl broadcast.

My husband watches the game.  I'm an Andy Reed fan, so sorry it's going so badly for KC....

Another Eagles TD as I write this.  It just keeps getting worse.
Unlike this puzzle, which just kept getting better.
I loved HIGHRESOLUTION!
My first ever unassisted Sunday and it was a romp with one of my fastest Su times ever. Great puzzle lol!
Fabulous, sumptuous, even voluptuous long clues and answers!
Wait, there are two well-known works of art which share the title "American Progress" and they're both by European men with four-letter surnames?   Woah.

There's nothing high-protein about paleo. The paleo diet simply entails eating foods that were available before the advent of agriculture. So while it's grain-free, it's not low-carb necessarily; some adherents replace their missing bread and soda with meat, some replace it with roots & fruits. I guess you missed the vegan paleo craze of the 2010s?

Steve,

A coincidence? I don't think so. Yes, RE comes from the Latin "thing," but you don't see a progression?

re
2 of 4
preposition
ˈrā  ˈrē 
: with regard to : in re

@Barry Ancona. The “re” in the French “regarder” from which we get “regard” has no etymological connection with the Latin “res”, it serves as an intensifier. So, I would say definitely coincidence. Unless, of course, you are arguing that the usage of “in re” some how arose from some unconscious connection, “convergence “, to Leigh regard.”
@Patrick J.  (Autocorrect strikes again) that last should read “in regard to”

@Barry Ancona The prefix RE- and the freestanding word RE both derive from Latin, but differently. Etymology of prefix RE-: https://www.etymonline.com/word/re- https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/re- Etymology of unattached word RE: https://www.etymonline.com/word/re https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/re It can also mean "a drop of golden sun," but that's just as irrelevant.
Steve and Patrick, Please click on this link Steve just provided and explain to me why it is only a coincidence: https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/re

@Barry Ancona. The coincidence is that the English word “regard” has no etymological connection with the Latin “in re”. They arrived in English by separate routes and happened to have similar meanings. What else can you call it?

@Barry Ancona As it says, the English word RE is not an abbreviation. It does not derive from the RE in reply, regarding, or reference. The freestanding word RE comes from RES, thing, one declension of rem, rebus, etc. RE- as a prefix also comes from Latin, but does not derive from the word RES. It is a prefix that means "back," "against" or "again." and derives ultimately from , from Latin re-, red- (“back; anew; again; against”), of uncertain origin but conjectured by Watkins to be from Proto-Indo-European *wret-, a metathetic alteration of *wert- (“to turn”). I'm going to try to send the Wiktionary link for RE- again, but it seems like the link leads to the page for hyphenless RE...so you wouldn't have seen the above. https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/re- If this leads to the RE page instead of the RE- page again, then just copy and paste the whole thing, including the hyphen. (That might have been the reason for the confusion.)

I understand the English word RE is not an abbreviation, and I know it doesn't come from the word regard (in English or French).

I understand RE comes from res, thing.

But IN RE means "with regard to," likely working its way from "this thing here."

The etymologies are different, but I don't think the result is a complete coincidence.
@Barry Ancona. P.S. As I have already written. The prefix RE in the French “regarder”  is not from the Latin “res”, but an intensifier. N

@Steve L 

Caitlin never said "re" was short for regarding. Putting "(garding)" is just a good visual way to elucidate the theme.
@Steve L Interestingly the 're' in 'republic' also comes from 'res', ie matters of the people (res publica)

Mr Dave, 

Caitlin said RE was an abbreviation.
It is not an abbreviation.
What did you miss?

"These expressions each include a letter pair that is commonly used as an abbreviation; understanding that, and mentally inserting the meaning of that abbreviation, is the key to figuring out this trick."

@Barry Ancona

Technically correct, but we use it the way we use other Latin expressions like “etc.” and “et al.”, that are abbreviations.  And it seems unlikely that “In re:” would have become so established as an expression if it didn’t align with “regarding”.  So a permissible description in my view. It certainly wouldn’t confuse anyone, even if slightly imprecise.

@Barry Ancona

If we are going to engage in the noble act of picking nits, she said it was “used” as an abbreviation, not that it *was* an abbreviation.  And she is, without any doubt, correct.

@Barry Ancona 

I was being specific. 

"These expressions each include a letter pair that is commonly used as an abbreviation..."

She could have meant "re" is an abbreviation for "in re" (which is true) which is synonymous with "regarding".

I thought a nitpicker would understand.

@Steve L

Late to the party, but I’d like to add that there are plenty of words in English that have come to have completely different meanings from their original. 

Re may indeed come from res, and the dictionary may provide that definition but if the vast majority of English speakers understand it (and therefore use it) to mean “regarding” — which especially appears to be the case when someone writes “in re”, then at a certain point that’s what it means. 

You all know all the examples of migratory meanings but I’ll throw out “media” for one. We use it as a singular even though it’s plural.

@SP 
The "chestnut" thing actually derives from a joke in a 19th century play.
One character is notorious for telling the same stories over and over again. When he starts to repeat one about a cork tree, another character interrupts to say, "Chestnut! It was a chestnut all the previous times you told it!"
(Or words to that effect.)
A sort of meme-before-memes ensued.

From my handy thesaurus, synonyms for barb:

"the barb on the hook cut his finger badly." spike, prong, point, projection, spur, thorn, needle, prickle, spine, quill, bristle, tine; technical spicule, spicula, spiculum, spinule.

Works for me.

@Eric Hougland 

Fair enough. I woke up with "barbed wire" in my head as a counterexample to the usage I learned as a child---no doubt there that the barb is just a spike.
I learned that the "barb" of a fishhook referred to both its point _and_ the backward-protruding spike behind it---both when I was fishing, and when I was having to cut that bit off the hook so I could extract fish hooks from people's faces, ears, scalps and hands when I worked in a Highland emergency department.
But that usage seems to be utterly unsupported by any "fishhook anatomy" diagram I can find online, in which the barb is just the spike behind the point. The etymological connection to "beard" makes that sense logical, too.
So, that seems to have been at best a local usage, at worst a misunderstanding among my teachers. 

That's my TIL, and it's not even lunchtime!

Barry, oh dear! Of course I meant to say etymology. 😆

Heathie,

"In re" does *mean* regarding. 
The re is not an *abbreviation* of regarding.

@HeathieJ 

Thanks!

And after reading the comments, I am under the impression that the "correction" was regarding (hah!) the etymology, and not whether it is understood as "regarding." 

Which reminds me of how the meaning of words change over time with usage and may not always correspond to their etymology.

The word "nice,"  when it was "necio," meant foolish. And while you may argue that it is foolish to be nice, I don't think anyone thinks that "nice" currently means "foolish."

@Renegator 

And here it is, hours later.

And I misremembered what I thought was the offender.

Both show up as past meanings.

Thanks for the succinct summary, Barry! That makes sense!  I should have said that I also always thought it was an abbreviation for regarding. So my long time understanding of its usage was correct but my assumption of where it came from was not.

It's funny, because re and in re are words I use a lot in emails but I had no idea the robust details behind it. It's just a thing I picked up along my career path. It's interesting to realize how much I take for granted or make assumptions about in our language.

I'm nowhere near a level of being able to discuss it like you and the others on that thread, but I do really find it interesting and appreciate the discussion. 

I sometimes catch the etymologist  Anatoly Lieberman on MPR and I always find it fascinating. Enough so that my husband bought me his book, but regretfully I never quite get to doing more than being fascinated by subject when I stumble upon it. One of these days I will delve into the book!

I'll stop rambling now!  ☺️

@Renegator 

It is interesting how they change over time, which often fills our comment section here. 

Similarly with grammar. I struggle a lot with how incredibly often I hear "and I" and "and me" incorrectly used. People seem to think these days that "and I" is correct way more than it is. I think they think it sounds more intelligent and it's become part of their language. I don't know, but I hear it at the highest levels of education, leadership, etc. It's amazing to me and constantly makes my head twitch. 

Every time I hear it on TV, I correct it out loud (my husband is such a lucky guy - ha ha!) because I won't correct it in real life. I guess I'm too, errr, nice.  It makes me wonder if the way I learned and have deeply imbedded it are no longer taught? Have the rules changed and I didn't know. Ahh, here I ramble again. 

Anyhow, interesting about nice. I would argue that it's more important to be kind, but yeah, I would never say nice means foolish.  It's an interesting connection though because I have seen that people can definitely be foolish in an effort to be nice, as you indicate.

@LARRY

“Hive mind” has been around the last few years. It refers to a group of people having a great deal of concurrence in their thinking. Often used in a critical way to suggest a lack of independent thought or open-mindedness.

@Barry Ancona hi! I responded to this later in the thread but didn’t include your “@“ so I don’t know if you’ll see it without me tagging you.

My claim is that the clue is inaccurate because churros are not from Mexico; they are Spanish. They eat them a lot in Mexico but calling them Mexican is what I disagree with.

CVR, 

Churros originated in Iberia, and they have become part of cuisines wherever there is or was Spanish or Portuguese influence.

A churro is a type of fried dough from Spanish and Portuguese cuisine, made with choux pastry dough piped into hot oil with a piping bag and large closed star tip or similar shape. They are also found in Latin American cuisine, Philippine cuisine and in other areas that have received immigration from Spanish and Portuguese-speaking countries, especially in France and the Southwestern United States. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Churro

@Barry Ancona right, so calling them Mexican isn’t really accurate, and leaves room for avoidable error. Perhaps using the clue “cylindrical Iberian pastry” would have been better, in my opinion. It’s fine if we don’t agree, and I did say I was perhaps being pedantic, but if  Churros are part of many Latin American cuisines, then it’s confusing to call them specifically Mexican; it’s like a red herring.

CVR,

No, it's called a crossword clue. It's allowed to be devious. The clue does *not* say churros are specifically Mexican. If my cousins in Mexico serve me churros, I'm not going to tell them they're serving me Spanish or Portuguese food. In New York, I've had churros in Mexican and Spanish restaurants.
